bibl.title: Hosaye Sakaguchi v. Henry M. White. Mandate
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: No. 5959 Law
United States of America, ss:
The President of the United States of America. To the Honorable the Judges of the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division,

Greeting: Whereas, lately in the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division, before you, or some of you in a cause between the Matter of the Petition of HOSAYE SAKAGUCHI, For a Writ of Habeas Corpus, No. 5959, a Judgement Dismissing Petition was duly filed on the 9th day of May, A.D. 1921, in the words and figures following to wit: * * * *

"It is therefore here and now ordered, adjudged and decreed, and the court does hereby order, adjudge and decree, that the said petition be dismissed and said writ of habeas corpus be denied and refused, and that the petitioner, Hosaye Sakaguchi, be and she is hereby remanded to the custody of Henry M. White, as U.S. Commissioner of Immigration for the Port of Seattle, for the execution of the judgement and order of deportation." * * * *

Which said Judgement is of record and fully set out in said cause in the office of the Clerk of the said District Court, to which record reference is hereby made and the same is hereby expressly made a part hereof, and

as by the inspection of the Transcript of the Record of the said District Court, which was brought into the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit by virtue of an appeal prosecuted by Hosaye Sakaguchi, as appellant, against Henry M. White, as United States Commissioner of Immigration at the Port of Seattle, Washington as appellee aggreably to the Act of Congress in such cases made and provided, fully and at large appears:

And Whereas, on the 20th day of September in the year of our Lord One Throusand Nine Hundred and Twenty-one the said cause came on to be heard before the said Circuit Court of Appeals, on the said Transcript of the Record and was duly argued and submitted:

On Consideration Whereof, It is not here ordered, adjudged, and decreed by this Court, that the judgment of the said District Court in this cause be, and hereby is reversed, and that this cause be and hereby is remanded to the said District Court with directions to discharge the appellant from custody. (January 9, 1992)

You, Therefore, are Hereby Commanded That such execution and further proceedings be had in the said cause in accordance with the opinion and decree of this Court, and as according to right and justice and the laws of the United States ought to be had, the said judgement of the said District Court notwithstanding.

Witness, the Honorable William Howard Taft, Chief Justice of the United States, the 9th day of February, in the year of our Lord One Thousand, Nine Hundred and Twenty-two and of the Independence of the United States of America the One Hundred and Forty-sixth.
F.D. Monckton, Clerk of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. By Paul P. O'Brien Deputy Clerk.
United States Circuit Court of Appeals Dor the Ninth Circuit
HOSAYE SAKAGUCHI, vs. HENRY M. WHITE, as United States Commissioner of Immigration at the Port of Seattle, Wash.
Mandate
J+D #3-Page 300
FILED IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION
F.M. HARSHBERGER, CLERK By S.E. Leitch, Deputy.
Let the within mandate be entered this 29th day of July 1922
Edward E. Cushman District Judge
